Uses of Interface
com.dkriesel.snipe.neuronbehavior.NeuronBehavior

Packages that use NeuronBehavior
com.dkriesel.snipe.core Contains the two core classes of SNIPE - NeuralNetworkDescriptor, which you use to outline and create instances of Neural Networks, and the NeuralNetwork class itself; Both of those classes' documentations, and the package documentation as well contain fundamental information to get used to SNIPE. 
com.dkriesel.snipe.neuronbehavior Contains several neuron behaviors, which are generalized activity functions, as well as an interface to implement customized ones. 
com.dkriesel.snipe.training Contains a class where to put in the training data for your neural network and one that contains several error measurement methods. 
 

Uses of NeuronBehavior in com.dkriesel.snipe.core

Uses of NeuronBehavior in com.dkriesel.snipe.neuronbehavior
 

Classes in com.dkriesel.snipe.neuronbehavior that implement NeuronBehavior
 class Fermi
          Implements the Fermi Function and its derivative.
 class Identity
          Implements the Identity Function and its derivative.
 class LeakyIntegratorExponential
          This class implements an exponential leaky integrator.
 class LeakyIntegratorLinear
          This class implements a simple linear leaky integrator.
 class TangensHyperbolicus
          Implements the Tangens Hyperbolicus and its derivative.
 class TangensHyperbolicusAnguita
          This class represents an numerically very simple approximation of the tanh function proposed by Anguita in "Speed Improvement of the Back-Propagation on Current Generation Workstations" by D.
 class TangensHyperbolicusAnguitaLeCun
          Like TangensHyperbolicusAnguita, but with scalings analogous to TangensHyperbolicusLeCun.
 class TangensHyperbolicusLeCun
          Implements the Tangens Hyperbolicus and its derivative in an optimized form by LeCun: f(x) = 1.7159*tanh((2/3)*x).

Uses of NeuronBehavior in com.dkriesel.snipe.training
 

Methods in com.dkriesel.snipe.training with parameters of type NeuronBehavior
 void TrainingSampleLesson.optimizeDesiredOutputsForClassificationProblem(NeuronBehavior function)
          If teaching classification problems you should consider placing the binary values at -x and x, where x is the absolute location of the absolute maxima of the 2nd derivative of the activation function (LeCun - Efficient Backprop).
